pageContext.desc: Written from the Oklahoma Territory, the Southwest, and the Dakotas, regarding his commissioned series of portraits of prominent Indian Chiefs.
transcription:
Wadsworth. Nevada.
April. 9. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I will send you
tomorrow 16 red drawings of
Pah-Ute Indians by W. F. Ex
Co.
I leave tomorrow forenoon for
Elko. Nevada. for the Shoshonie
Indians.
As far as I know now there
are three different tribes of Indians
in Nevada viz Washoe, Pah Ute
and Shoshonie. There are several
bands of the Pah Ute living
in different parts of Nevada and
Utah but people tell me that
the different bands living in Nevada
are the same tribe.
I have the Pah Ute well represented
in the red drawings. I made a
portrait today of a very old
Indian he is so old he can

hardly walk, he could not come to
my room so I went to his house
and he sat for me, The Indians
say he is 150 years old and he
looks it by the wrinkles in his
face his white name is
"Old Hickory" and his Indian name
is "Wood-ted'tard" he is a fine old
subject and he has been in many
fights with soldiers and white
people, a few miles from here is a
battle ground where a fight occurred between the Pah Ute
Indians and soldiers and great many
years ago, the old man said he
was a young man when that fight 
took place.
These Indians have all the meat
they want in fish, they catch fish
and cut it in a thin slice and
dry it by hanging it out doors.
I have had good success here,
worked hard.

(3) 
After I am through with Nevada
I will go to California and first go
to the Digger Indians they, like
the Pah Utes are scattered around
in different places in California
I have now four places to choose
from but I will go where I will
find the most Digger Indians
to choose from.
These Pah Ute Indians do not
seem to make as fine a basket as
the Pah Utes at Carson City.
You will notice quite a difference
in the type between a Pah Ute and
a Washoe, the Pah Ute is a finer
type than the Washoe and a more
capable Indian they remind me
more of the Apache.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. You can address me
to Elko. Nevada.

Elko. Nevada.
April. 11. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I arrived here last night.
There are good types of the
Shoshonie Indians here they
live just out side of the town in
wooden houses.
They are little short stockey built
Indians and very independent
hope I will have good success in
getting them to sit for me. I just
got me a nice place to work
in and board.
I have written to have Henry
get the portraits of Indians I
have stored in Sibleys taken over
to your office and have them
take care of them for me there which
I hope will not inconvenience
you any. I would rather have
them at your Office in your
care than at Sibleys.

It cost me over $6.00 a month
for the things I have stored at
Sibleys and no telling how long
they would have to be stored there.
I have a lot of frames there with
no pictures in and Indian baskets,
Those I will have sent to Harvard.
I sent you some good types
from Wadsworth of the Pah-
Utes.
I will write you soon again,
as I know more about these
Shoshonie Indians.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Elko. Nevada.
April. 16. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am having a hard time
to get these Indians to sit for me
but am getting them all right only
it takes an awful lot of talk and
explaining.
Years ago, here an old Medicine
Shoshoni Indian here died and
before he died he told all these
Indians not to allow any pictures
taken of them by the whites, he told
them that the white people were
trying to get rid of the Indians
that when a white man took a
picture of an Indian he rubbed
poison in the picture and the
Indian was taken sick and died
so you can see what I have to
contend with, when I go around where
They are they act afraid and glad
when I walk away. I got
acquainted with an intelligent looking

Shoshoni Indian he speaks good
English and I took him to my room
and showed him some of my pictures
of Indians and got him to sit for
me, after a lot of talking and since
then I have had four other Indians
sit for me, today an old fellow
and a fine subject sat for me. I think I
will get the whole family of his.
These are good types here, smaller
than the Pah Ute but strong faces.
A great many of them live in
a village of their own near town. 
I was out to their village this
morning and got the old fellow.
This tribe here makes scarcely any
baskets they are great gamblers.
I will remain here until I get
what types I want.
These Shoshonies here tell me that
they are not the same tribe of Shoshonies
that live in Wyoming they say
they speak a different language.

(3) I have seen the Shoshonies from
Wyoming and they are small people
same as these only a wilder looking 
Indian than these.
You can address me to 
Colfax. California as I go
there from here for the Digger 
Indians.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Elko. Nevada.
April. 23rd. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am sending you by
W.F. Ex Co today 18 red drawings
17 are Shoshonie and one Pah-Ute.
I never worked harder in my
life or talked more or schemed
more to get these Shoshonie Indians
to sit for me and I am lucky to
get 17 portraits, a good many
of these Indians look upon me
as an enemy and bad medicine.
Some times when I would approach
them they would growl at me
and some would run away and not
speak to me.
I think most of them will be
glad when I go away from here.

But I was determined to get a
good representative of the tribe.
I had a fine old subject Today
in an old Indian man, he was a
hard customer to get, and as
soon as the portrait was finished
he did'nt loose much time in
getting out of my room
A traveling man was here a few
days ago and wanted to take some
photographs of these Indians he
could'nt get one, he finally did'nt
even dare expose his camera.
Some of these Indians live in the 
old style Tepee such as the plains
Indians used to live in but most
of these Indians live in wooden
houses, They do odd jobs around
town and in mines and on 
ranches.
This tribe finishes me up with

the Indians in Nevada. I go to
Colfax. California from here for the
Digger Indians.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Colfax. California.
April. 26. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here yesterday
noon and commenced to work this
morning, had a good subject in
a Digger Indian man to sit for 
me.
I have been told several times that
the Digger Indians were the lowest in
humanity of any of the American
Indians that is a great mistake
they impress me as a superior
race of Indians, they speak the
best English of any Indians I
have so far been to and are
very intelligent, bright people and
clean in regard to their personal 
appearance.

The Digger Indians are fast disappearing
there are only some 15 here they live in
different places in California in
small bands, they are very industrious
fine looking Indians they live out side
of the town in wooden houses and
some of them raise a small crop and
they do odd jobs for the whites.
I will get all I want of these
Indians as they take kindly to sitting
for their portraits they are not
superstitious at all in regard to
sitting for me. The old Indian
who sat for me today was born
a little ways from here, he told
me that all the Digger Indians
living in California belong to one
tribe.
They make good baskets.
It seems nice to get back to
California where there is green
grass and flowers in bloom

In Nevada it was all sand and
sage brush.
I have a nice place to board and
a good room to work in.
I have been told of some Indians
South East of here in California that I have
never heard of before, they live in
the mountains near the Nevada
State line several miles from a
railroad, These Indians are called
The Pannamint Indians, The Government
does not mention such a tribe in my
book, the man who told me about
these Indians said he used to live
there and knows these Indians, So I
will go there from here.
There are several tribes of Indians
the Government does not mention
in my book, that I have been to
because they receive no rations and

and are self supporting and these
Pannamint Indians are self supporting.
This is a nice town located in the 
mountains.
I will write you again soon
from here.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Colfax. California.
May. 7. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I sent you today by
W.F. Ex Co 24 red
drawings 18 are Digger Indians
4 are Shoshoni and 2 Washoe.
I leave here this week for
Auburn Calif which is 18 miles
from here I will be there but a
few days for Digger Indians,
Then I go 40 miles by wagon
from Johannesburg Calif
for The Pannamint Indians.
I am having good success with
these Indians, they are nice people.
They do not seem to live together
much but their homes are scattered
around. Lately I have had to go

down in a Canon where one family
of the Digger's lived it was a hard
walk there especially coming back
climbing up the mountain.
These Indians do but very little
farming, some of them have a small
garden, they depend upon working
for the white people for a living
and are very much civilized,
nearly all of them speaks good English.
These Diggers here tell me that
there is a tribe of Digger Indians
living near Chico Calif that are
a different Digger tibe from these
here, they say they speak a different
language and can not understand
each others Indian language.
You can address me to
Johannesburg. California.
Kern Co.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Ballaret. California
Inyo. Co.
May. 14. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here this evening
I had a long journey to get
here over 400 miles by rail and
70 miles by Stage.
I was told at Johannesburg
where I took the Stage that I
was coming to the toughest place
on the Earth, well it is the
toughest place I ever have been 
to. It is a mining camp only
miners live here and most
of the miners are Irish. this is
a small place scarcely 100 people
here and there are three saloons
here, on the way we met a
man coming from here and

he told us every one was drunk
here, well he told pretty much the
truth, but as long as one minds
his own business he is all right,
we had to cross a desert
of sand and miles of borax
for 60 miles and then cross a
mountain to get here this place
is at the foot of the Pannamint
mountains the Pannamint
Indians are 7 miles from here
I saw one tonight and had a 
talk with him he is coming
tomorrow to sit for me.
I never heard of these Indians
before a few weeks ago, the
Government does not mention
them in their book and a man
at Wadsworth Nevada told
me about them, when I got
to Kramer where I changed cars

(3)
for here and which is 100
miles from here I asked a fellow
in the store there about these
Pannamint Indians he said he
never heard of such a tribe here &
told me there were no Indians
here but I went on to Johannesburg
and saw the Stage driver for here
and he said there were Pannamint
Indians here so I came on.
The day I left Colfax Calif.
I went out to a village where
the Digger Indians used to live
only two old Indian men live there now,
it is four and one half miles
there and I walked out, I got
there as one old Indian man was cooking
his breakfast which was coffee
and pounded acorns, he would
not sit for me, said he was
nearly blind that all he could

see was the fire before him he
said he was so old his hands
shook, so I went to the other
old Indian man and he was
also sick, said he did'nt
want his picture made when
he felt and looked sick. I
argued with him, but he would
not sit for me, so I walked
back to town and took the
train for Auburn Calif where a
family of Digger Indians
lived. I called on them but they
were not home so I came here.
On my way I had to go to
Oakland Calif and went across
the bay to San Francisco and
the newspapers and pictures do
not give one any idea of the
awful disaster there, imagine
4 miles wide and 8 miles

(5)
long of solid built buildings
the very finest in S.F. all a
mass of twisted iron brick and
stone except 3 or 4 buildings left standing. 
I saw streets there that
had sunk from one foot to
5 feet, and buildings knocked
in all kinds of shapes, the
shock it self was awful
furniture in a room was shoved
from one side of room to other
side & jumped up and down in
the room. I slept in a wooden
house in S.F. one night where
an Artist friend of mine was
stopping, the people are not
allowed to use only candles
for a light and all have
to cook out in the streets. so
the streets where the fire did
not burn are lined with
all kinds of cooking stoves

and three and four families
will cook on one stove,
As I was walking through
the ruins I met an old
inappropriate reference I asked him if he
was in this, and I did have
to laugh to hear that old man
tell me all about the earthquake
and fire, how scared he was
and how he ran, He said he
thought the devil was after him.
I told him, he surely was, no
sir he says he was not for he
says he never did the devil
any harm. I says well where
are you going now, he replied
I dont know sir.
I expect to be here two weeks
These Pannamint Indians are
small people like the Shoshoni

(7)
and resemble them, they work
for the white people in the
mines, they are named after
the Panniment range of
mountains here. They surely live
in a wild country the wildest
looking country I ever have been
in. There is no style here all the
men wear a slouch hat blue
jean pants and a shirt.
I put my old clothes on at
Johannesburg but I looked
dressed up to the Proprietor
of this shack of a Hotel, he told 
me this was a rough place for
me, he said if I was not suited
with the meals and my room
I could get out. I told him I
had slept in Indian houses
and eaten with the Indians.
Well he says, you are all right

for here Then. He said he was
good friends with these Indians
and would help me all he could, 
but I dont need his help as I
can manage the Indians my
own way better.
The mines here are gold mines.
I will write you again in
a few days.
You can address me to
Ballaret. Inyo Co.
California.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Ballarat. Inyo Co.
California.
May. 15. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I had a Panamint
Indian sitting for me Today.
These Panamint Indians are
renegades and live around these
mountains.
The Indian today told me there
were only 9 Panamint Indians
living and most of these nine
are 28 miles from here in the
mountains called "Junction", so
day after tomorrow I believe I will
go there and live in their camp
with them as I can not depend
upon their coming here.
The Government has absolutely
nothing to do with these Indians

They dont go to school at all
and live entirely in secluded
places in the mountains and only
come to places where they can get
sugar flour etc whey they have to.
They very seldom go where there is
a railroad and do not know much
about the Indians who live 100
miles from them, they seem to be
nice people, what little I have seen
on them, The Indian today told me
they still live in brush houses
same as years ago. I am told they
make very fine baskets. I will 
go to this camp and get all
of them to sit for me if I can.
This is a tough place but the
people are kind to me, There is a
good deal of mining excitement
around here, lots of prospectors
here.

(3)
The mail comes here three times
a week, there are three saloons and
one store here.
Water is quite a problem in this
part of the country, drinking water
has to be hauled a few miles.
I will write you again
soon.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

(Junction) Ballarat Inyo Co.
California.
May. 17. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I left Ballarat today
and came here 28 miles by wagon
These Pannamint Indians roam around
and when the weather gets hot in The Valley They
move up in the mountains so I
moved also, their camp is from
two to 4 miles from here.
I am stopping with a man
who has lived West most of his
life, he has a stock ranch here
and lives alone except now
and then when a traveler happens
along and stops with him a few
days, he does his own cooking
and is a fine cook, he is also

a miner and seems to be a well read
man.
An old Pannamint Indian was
here as I came along as is coming
tomorrow to sit for me, he is quite a
noted character, these Pannamint Indians
raise quite a good deal of stock, on this
side of the mountain there is good
feed for stock.
Ballarat is an awful tough town,
a place where miners and prospectors
go to buy goods and get drunk,
those who wish to, last night I
could scarcely sleep such an awful
racket singing, hollering and dancing
nearly all night.
I think I will get most of the
Pannamint Indians to sit for me.
Tomorrow when I have made the
portraits of the old Indian I will 
go to his camp with him

(3)
They live in the old style brush houses.
I probably will be through here
the latter part of next week I have
had a long ways to go and hard 
traveling to get these Indians, 98
miles over the roughest country mostly
a desert.
From here I will go to Chico Calif
for the other tribe of Digger Indians
The Digger Indians told me at 
Colfax Calif that they were a different
tribe from them. They live some 200
miles from each other.

This man here has got a fine

stock ranch, every thing is nice and
neat around his place. I have a
nice room to sleep in and work in
You can address me to
Ballarat Calif Inyo Co. as I

go through there to get to the
railroad.

(Junction) Ballarat. Inyo Co.
Calif.
May. 19. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I guess I will have to
content my self with but portraits
of two Panamint Indians and those
two are men.
Yesterday an old Panamint Indian
sat for me. I asked him if the
Panamint women would sit for me
and he said no, said they were afraid
to, well I says I will go to your
camp with you and see them and
have a talk with them, he said
all right, when he started for his
camp I went with him, after
going a mile he said I am going
in the mountains to hunt jackrabbit
and left me. I asked him to
show me where he lived. he said

you see mountain my camp is
other side of that mountain, so
I went other side of that mountain
which was a good 7 mile walk.
I followed a buck trail and
supposed I was right, but there
was no camp there, the old fellow
deceived me, he did'nt want me to
go to his camp, but on returning 
home I noticed off to the
right of me what looked like
a camp but too far to go to then
as it was getting dark and I was
afraid of getting lost so I came
right home and this morning
I got up early and walked five
miles and found their camp. it
was in a secluded place one could
not see it until right on it almost

(3)
Six Panamint Indians were there, 
two women and a little girl, the old
man was there and I could see they
did not like it because I came,
They all jabbered away and were
mad I said nothing for quite a
while about their sitting for me
and when I did approach the
subject the women became very angry
one old woman was making a
basket, they had quite a few baskets
there, I wanted to buy one but the
old woman gathered up her baskets
and went off and hid, pretty soon
another Panamint Indian came, a 
good natured looking fellow and I
had quite a long talk with him.
I offered the women twice what
I pay the Indians to sit for me and
they would not sit, they simply were
afraid they would die if a picture

was made of them, finally one of the
Indians said, A long time ago
a white man came in this country
and made pictures of all the
Panamint Indians except us, we
happened to be away at the time
and every one of those Indians that
a picture was made of died and
we lived, that is why he says these
women will not sit for you. I tried
to get him to take me to Johannesburg
98 miles from here but he said he
could not as he had a sick boy
and tomorrow he was going to take
him to some hot springs in the 
mountains, to day is Saturday and
I have got to stay here until next
Monday when the stage comes along
and go to Ballerat and the next
day take another stage for Johannesburg
I am very lucky to get the two

(5)
Panamint Indians to sit for me.
These Panamint Indians live the nearest
to the way Indians used to live of any
I have been to. their life is an out door
life, they had a nice camp sheltered
from the wind and in the hot months
roam around in the mountains.

They had a lot of fine horses and

seemed to have quite a stock of horses
on the range. I asked them again
how many Panamint Indians were
living and they said only nine.
I will try and get some white man
to take me to the railroad before the
stage goes if I can.
I am stopping at a nice ranch
good food and good water, the
man who owns the ranch was
born in England.
Your affectionate nephew

Elbridge.

Darwin California
May 20th 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
The man who owned the
Stock ranch at Junction where
I was yesterday advised me to come 
here 20 miles by stage, he said
two Panamint Indian women
lived here and one had married
a Frenchman and he thought they
would sit for me, and as the stage
was coming here that afternoon I
packed my things and came here,
the Stage driver introduced me to
the Frenchman and I had a long
talk with him and he said his
wife he thought would sit for
me, said he would talk to her.
I saw her sitting in the yard

with a lot of Shoshoni Indians
gambling. The Frenchman told me
to call after Supper and as I
approached him after Supper he
laughed and said, say the minute
I talked picture to my wife and
those other Indians they hollered out
no no no and all lit out
but he says you come again
tomorrow and in the mean time
I will have a good talk with her.
I have just come from his place
and he said they would not
sit under any circumstances.
I noticed the women gambling
and I walked over to them and
gave a little Indian girl and 
Indian boy each five cents
which pleased their Mothers, but 
I did not dare talk picture

(3)
only in a round about way
told them I had been with the
Shoshoni Indians at Elko
Nevada and made a lot of
pictures of them there as soon as
I said picture the women commenced
to jabber away in their own language
and looked scared, so now tomorrow
I go 110 miles by stage to
Johannesburg and take the
cars and go direct to Chico
Calif for the other tribe of
Digger Indians I have done all
I can to get these Panamite Indians
to sit for me and I feel very
lucky to have two of the Indian
men sit for me.
This town is another mining town
a pretty tough place but good
big hearted people here and all
seem to take an interest in my
pageContext.category: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection; Indians of North America; Letters (Correspondence)
pageContext.title: E.A. Burbank letters, 1906
